title: PSU coach orders protest shirts with the slogan 'chains, tattoos, dreads, we are' confiscated
text:
Penn State officials confiscated T-shirts from players prior to Saturday night's game at Iowa, as players wore the shirts during pregame warmups as a show of support to Penn State safety Jonathan Sutherland.

Photos posted to social media showed players wearing white T-shirts with the words 'Chains, Tattoos, Dreads & WE ARE' on the front.

Nittany Lions head coach James Franklin was upset that his players did not discuss the issue with him beforehand.

Scroll down for videos

Photos posted to social media showed players wearing white T-shirts with the words 'Chains, Tattoos, Dreads & WE ARE' on the front

While the shirts were in support of Penn State safety Jonathan Sutherland, Nittany Lions head coach James Franklin was upset that his players did not discuss the issue with him beforehand

Penn State issued a statement during the game that read:

'While we are supportive of our students expressing themselves in a thoughtful manner, they are expected to wear team-issued apparel on game day. We asked our students to remove the shirts out of an abundance of caution for NCAA compliance.'

Earlier this week, Sutherland posted online a letter he received from a man claiming to a Penn State alum. In the letter, the man who identified himself as David Petersen, said he and his wife, 'miss the clean cut young men and women from those days.

The letter went on to state that while Petersen believes Sutherland will one day play in the NFL, he and his wife 'have stopped watching the NFL due to the disgusting tattoos, awful hair and immature antics in the end zone.'

The offensive letter states: 'Surely there must be mirrors in the locker room! Don't you have parents or girlfriend who've told you those shoulder length dreadlocks look disgusting and are certainly not attractive'

"𝘛𝘩𝘦 𝘧𝘰𝘰𝘵𝘣𝘢𝘭𝘭 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘐 𝘬𝘯𝘰𝘸 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘭𝘰𝘷𝘦 𝘣𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨𝘴 𝘱𝘦𝘰𝘱𝘭𝘦 𝘵𝘰𝘨𝘦𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘦𝘮𝘣𝘳𝘢𝘤𝘦𝘴 𝘥𝘪𝘧𝘧𝘦𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘦𝘴..."



-@coachjfranklin#WeAre pic.twitter.com/evcDBtR01L — Penn State Football (@PennStateFball) October 8, 2019

On Tuesday, Franklin denounced the letter and offered impassioned support of Sutherland, a sophomore. And following the team's victory against Iowa, Sutherland posted a video showing the coach wearing a dreadlock wig as he laughed with the athlete.

On Tuesday, Franklin denounced the letter and offered impassioned support of Sutherland, a sophomore.

And following the team's victory against Iowa, Sutherland posted a video showing the coach wearing a dreadlock wig as he laughed with the athlete.

Champs Downtown, the sports bar that banned Petersen following the release of the letter, was responsible for creating the shirts.

The shirt was pulled from their website and social media postings following the news of Coach Franklin's sentiment.

Sutherland released a statement saying that he took 'no personal offense' to what was said, clarifying that it was 'rude' and 'ignorant'

Champs does sell other shirts that have chains on them. The shirts sell for $15

And while they could not clarify why the shirt was removed, a spokesman from the bar did tell DailyMail.com that Petersen is still banned from the establishment.

The team has rallied around Sutherland since the letter was released, with former quarterback Jake Zembiec sporting chains from the sidelines

'Yes the ban is in effect however we don't want to focus on the negative,' said Dante Lucchesi, creative director and Manager of Champs.

'One of our core values is support of the football program and players. The layers go out on the field every Saturday.

He continued: 'They are the ones winning the games for us so we have always supported the players.'

Champs does sell other shirts that have chains on them. The shirts sell for $15.

The team has rallied around Sutherland since the letter was released, with former quarterback Jake Zembiec sporting chains from the sidelines.

He also posted a video to his story of the team in the locker room, enjoying themselves after beating No. 17 Iowa in a huge Big Ten clash on Saturday.

Earlier in the week, teammate C.J. Holmes took to Twitter to share a copy of the letter Sutherland received from a person who identified themselves as Dave Petersen.

'My teammate got this in the mail today, and tbh Im at a lost for words,' Holmes shared in the tweet that has been liked more than 38,000 times and has more than 10,000 retweets.

The letter was directed towards the sophomore and asked why his family didn't tell him that the hairstyle was ugly

'I also have locs, Tats, and NFL dreams too, these messages can not be tolerated, this was extremely inappropriate, racially biased, and selfish to feel like you even have a right to send this message #WeAre.'

In the letter, Petersen explains that he and his wife are 'older' graduates of Penn state who 'follow all Penn State sports.'

Petersen boasts that he played full court basketball well into his 50s, before admitting that he 'never had the size of the talent' to reach Sutherland's level 'though the desire was there.'

'Though the athletes of today are certainly superior to those in my days; we miss the clean cut young men and women from those days,' the alum declared. 'Watching the Idaho game on TV we couldn't help but notice your -well - awful hair.

The offensive letter continued: 'Surely there must be mirrors in the locker room! Don't you have parents or girlfriend who've told you those shoulder length dreadlocks look disgusting and are certainly not attractive.'

Petersen informs Sutherland that he represents 'all Penn Staters' before voicing his support for a 'reappearance of dress codes for athletes.'

Teammate C.J. Holmes took to Twitter to share a copy of the letter Sutherland received. He declared that those types of messages could not be tolerated

The school has voiced their support for Sutherland and other athletes at the school

The sentiment was shared by Sandy Barbour, the Vice President of Intercollegiate Athletics at the school

The Penn State alum shares that he and his wife no longer watch the NFL due to the 'disgusting, tattoos, awful hair and immature antics in the end zone.' Petersen acknowledges that he expects Sutherland to play 'on Sunday' but warns that he behaves.

'Players should act as though they've 'been there before,'' he concluded.

The letter has quickly gone viral on social media, with many trying to figure out Petersen's identity.

Several opinion articles were attributed to the Johnstown resident. The letter were often outdated complaints

Social media users found an email associated with Petersen for alumni at the university, but his alumni page has been taken down. It was speculated that he graduated from Penn State in 1966.

Sutherland has not said much about the letter. He and a woman believed to be his girlfriend have shared photos of the star athlete with his locs in full swing

Several opinion articles were attributed to Petersen, who resided in Johnstown at the time.

One 2010 letter to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette went on a long tirade against tattoos.

'The full back tattoo displayed by the 19-year-old hairdresser is unbelievably disgusting and disturbing. She had a lovely body which is now permanently deformed and disfigured,' he said.

'Young people with face/neck tattoos and face/body piercing are really sickening. Most parents would move heaven and earth to seek medical attention if their child were born with visible (even nonvisible) body markings or scars.'

Sutherland has not said much about the letter. He and a woman believed to be his girlfriend have shared photos of the star athlete with his locs in full swing.

The school has voiced their support for Sutherland and other athletes at the school.

Champs Downtown, a local bar in the area, shared a photo banning Petersen from ever watching sporting events at their establishment

'While we don't know the source of this letter or the authenticity, obviously its content does not align with our values,' the school said in a statement on Twitter. 'We strongly condemn this message or any message of intolerance.'

The sentiment was shared by Sandy Barbour, the Vice President of Intercollegiate Athletics at the school, who added: I stand with our Penn State student athletes and appreciate how they represent PSU in competition, in the classroom and in the community.

'Their dress, tattoos, or hairstyle has no impact on my support, nor does their gender, skin color, sexuality or religion! #WeAre #ONETEAM.'

Champs Downtown, a local bar in the area, shared a photo banning Petersen from ever watching sporting events at their establishment.
description: Jonathan Sutherland sported the white T-shirts with the words 'Chains, Tattoos, Dreads & WE ARE' on the front. His team has been supportive, even wearing chains to most of their games.
